Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Naturally Inspired Resilient, Sustainable and Adaptable Infrastructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

Over 300 Billion dollars in damages were incurred in 2017 due to extreme weather in the U.S., a new record in terms of both direct and indirect losses. In addition to losses from weather-related events, extreme geologic and human-caused disasters can cause staggering financial burdens to the economy. The need for understanding what makes communities resilient whereby they can adapt and recover quickly from these events is fundamental to the survival of the nation. We propose that a key to understanding how to effectively and efficiently recovery from these extreme events is to examine natural systems that inherently resist, adapt, and evolve to ever-evolving stressors. Ecological resilience examines the ability of a natural system to respond to disturbances and measures the system's ability to return to a functioning state. While humans seek resiliency and sustainability through simplification and order, the diversity and complexity of natural systems is what makes them resilient & sustainable. Therefore, understanding the attributes that make a system resilient requires an understanding of both the individual components of the system and the interdependencies of these components. The uniqueness of this potential Engineering Research Center (ERC) is our hypothesis in that it is not the study of individual organisms that is the key to resilience, but the study of the systems that these organisms inhabit and enable. Nature has provided an avenue for developing analysis methods, models and systems that provide resilience to extreme events and conditions. The mission of this planning grant is to develop the team and structure of transdisciplinary research that examines the attributes of resilient natural systems, create collaborations between innovative researchers, and construct an infrastructure that allows for collaborative research leading to economic development through tech transfer. A successful grant would provide research leading to substantially improved national defense facilities and networks, the next generation of resilient and efficient infrastructure, and adaptable community planning. The knowledge gained would inform community leaders, planners, engineers and the public on mitigating the impact of and recovering from extreme events.

The integration of knowledge, disciplines and methods that span science and engineering required to provide comprehensive approaches to infrastructure and community resilience is found in natural systems. By considering multi-scale research from the organism to system levels, we anticipate dramatic increases to the state of the art in a) adaptable, sustainable and efficient materials and forms for use in infrastructure, b) leveraging the interdependencies in systems to improve human community resilience, c) developing algorithms for optimization, integration and adaptability of built infrastructure based on natural processes, and d) improved pedagogical approaches for development of innovative designers and community leaders. This planning grant will take a novel approach to developing transdisciplinary research teams that embrace both creativity and diversity, and that provide mechanisms for inclusion across institutional classifications. The model for the center will itself model natural systems by recognizing that interdependencies between researchers are as important as the expertise of the individual researchers. The research team recognizes that not all ERC planning grants will lead to successfully funded ERCs. However, the planning process will still provide significant broader impacts including development of 1) Multi-scale, transdisciplinary teams to appropriately tackle biomimicry for resilient and sustainable structures 2) Industrial partnerships for tech transfer, innovation and economic development in the area of biomimicry 3) Organizational structures that promote shared resources, engaged teaming and broad diversity, 4) An identified network of researchers capable of creative synthesis across disciplinary boundaries and 5) Recognition of diverse teaming beyond the limits of "visually identifiable" demographic diversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BIO-ARC was proposed to the National Science Foundation as an Engineering Research Center (ERC) that focuses on the fundamental problem: that infrastructure has historically not been resilient to a wide range of crises, disasters, and conditions. Biological systems, however are resilient to a myriad of crises, disasters and conditions. Much of biological system resiliency comes from their ability to adapt and the interdependence of system components and associated redundancies. The BIO-ARC will study natural systems to reveal the underlaying structures, materials, synergies and system interactions that empower these systems to survive and thrive, supporting the constituent populations. The stakeholders to the BIO-ARC are those who play key roles in infrastructure systems, public policy or planning, education and training, and/or First Response.

This award was a planning grant for the research team to develop the pre-proposal for the National Science Foundation’s 2019 and subsequent ERC competitions. The research team utilized the award to hold two in person workshops at CSU and Princeton to develop the ERC as well as several other day long web meetings and an myriad of web conferences. The research team cam together from their diverse backgrounds to converge upon a team science approach for the BIO-ARC. The pre-proposal for the BIO-ARC was submitted to NSF in 2019, but was not awarded.

 Over 300 Billion dollars in damages were incurred in 2017 due to extreme weather events alone, a new record in economic cost to the US.  These costs include damage to infrastructure and loss of economic productivity (NOAA 2018). Add to this the damages and losses through geologic extreme events and anthropogenic events, and the economic losses to private and public infrastructure are staggering. The need for resilient communities that can adapt and recover quickly from stochastic and malevolent events is fundamental to the success of the nation. One component of that resilience is considered a grand Challenge of the NAE, “Restore and Improve Urban Infrastructure” (NAE 2017). We propose that a key to reducing the impact of both stochastic and malevolent events on communities in the most economical and sustainable manner is to examine systems that inherently resist, adapt and evolve to withstand extreme events such as ecosystems, microbial communities, and biomes.

 While humans seek resiliency and sustainability through simplification and order, the diversity and complexity of natural systems is what makes them resilient & sustainable. This dichotomy has been noted in the past (NAE 1996) when examining natural organisms and systems to inspire engineered systems and materials. However, the unique novelty of this Engineering Research Center (ERC) that we propose is that it is not the study of individual organisms that are the key to the next generation of infrastructure, but the study of the resilient, adaptive, and sustainable systems that these organisms inhabit and enable. Indeed, of the four distinct kinds of sustainability in infrastructure and human communities [human, economic, social, and environmental], we hypothesize that the study of these successful natural systems will inform success in all four aspects. Nature has provided an avenue for developing analysis methods, models and systems that provide resilience to extreme events and conditions.

The BIO-ARC team is a joint venture of Princeton University, Colorado State University, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, Smith College and University of Minnesota at Mankato. The team’s leadership come from conventional infrastructure engineering backgrounds: civil, structural geotechnical and industrial. Analogous to diversity being key to system function in ecosystems, diversity of contributors will be key to the success of the BIO-ARC.  

The principle outcome of this award was the BIO-ARC pre-proposal that was submitted to NSF in 2019. Other impacts of the award include the ongoing collaborative, convergent, team science research that was initiated through this planning grant. The final impact to the award are seven other funding proposals developed by the collaborators from the connections, understandings, and new knowledge developed in the planning grant activities funded by this award.
